thread.title: Trump Attacks McCain For Criticizing Outcome Of Yemen Raid
thread.title_full: Trump Attacks McCain For Criticizing Outcome Of Yemen Raid

author: Charles Campbell
title: Trump Attacks McCain For Criticizing Outcome Of Yemen Raid
text:
Trump Attacks McCain For Criticizing Outcome Of Yemen Raid "He's been losing so long ..." by Charles Campbell February 9, 2017 at 2:22pm Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
The tense feud between President Donald Trump and Senator John McCain shows no signs of cooling down anytime soon. 
On Thursday, the Arizona Republican received the brunt-end of a tweet storm after he criticized the president’s decision to call the recent mission in Yemen a success. 
“While many of the objectives of the recent raid in Yemen were met, I would not describe any operation that results in the loss of American life as a success,” McCain said in a statement Wednesday. Advertisement - story continues below Three In A Row: O’Reilly Extends Ratings Winning Streak Over Schwarzenegger 
The president proceeded to tear into McCain on Twitter. Sen. McCain should not be talking about the success or failure of a mission to the media. Only emboldens the enemy! He's been losing so…. 
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 9, 2017 …long he doesn't know how to win anymore, just look at the mess our country is in – bogged down in conflict all over the place. Our hero.. 
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 9, 2017 Advertisement - story continues below 
Trump concluded saying, “Ryan died on a winning mission (according to General Mattis), not a ‘failure.’ Time for the U.S. to get smart and start winning again!” 
White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer agreed with the assessment, saying the raid was “absolutely a success.” 
Spicer mentioned, without giving a specific name, that anyone who spread the notion that the mission was not successful should apologize. 
“I think anybody who undermines the success of that raid owes an apology … to the life of Chief Owens,” Spicer said at a press briefing. Advertisement - story continues below
